summary: Email correspondence between a paralegal and a Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) staff member regarding FOIA litigation filed by the NY Times for Epstein records. The email discusses the location and origin of various logbooks from MCC New York related to Epstein's incarceration and suicide watch, and the process for copying and maintaining these documents.

persons.name: Nicole
persons.context: Mentioned as someone who received a set of documents from the MCC staff member regarding the FOIA litigation.

persons.name: Kara
persons.context: Author of the email, working on the FOIA litigation filed by the NY Times regarding Epstein records, asking detailed follow-up questions about document searches and logbooks.

persons.name: Lt. Doctor
persons.context: Mentioned as the person who received photocopies of original logbooks from the MCC staff member and subsequently released them to the FBI.

connections.description: Kara references documents previously provided to Nicole, indicating a professional workflow in the FOIA litigation process.
The MCC staff member made photocopies of logbooks and turned them over to Lt. Doctor of the SIS department, who then released them to the FBI.

locations: MCC New York 150 Park Row New York NY 10007
2nd floor suicide watch area (Psychology Observation log, Suicide Watch log)
keyFacts: The document is part of FOIA litigation filed by the NY Times regarding Epstein records, indicating ongoing legal and media scrutiny.

Multiple specific logbooks from Epstein's incarceration at MCC New York are detailed, including Attorney Conference, Lobby Attorney, Visual Search, Psychology Observation, Suicide Watch, and Intake Screening Phone logs.
The original logbooks were photocopied by MCC staff, turned over to the SIS department (Lt. Doctor), and then released to the FBI, establishing a chain of custody.
Log entries specifically reference dates in July 2019 (including July 23, 24, and 8) related to Epstein's suicide watch and psychological observation.
The correspondence reveals internal MCC document management practices, including the use of a personal drive folder to maintain scanned Epstein-related documents for request fulfillment.
